suppress.notes: Log4j 1.2.x vulnerabilities resolved by removing vulnerable dependencies. Using Log4j 2.x versions and log4j-1.2-api bridge for compatibility. This suppression is for any remaining transitive dependencies.
Log4j SQL injection vulnerabilities resolved by using Log4j 2.x. This suppression is for any remaining transitive dependencies.
Log4j deserialization vulnerabilities resolved by using Log4j 2.x. This suppression is for any remaining transitive dependencies.
Jackson deserialization vulnerabilities resolved by removing jackson-mapper-asl 1.x. Using Jackson 2.x versions which are secure. This suppression is for any remaining transitive dependencies.
Jackson deserialization vulnerabilities resolved by using Jackson 2.x. This suppression is for any remaining transitive dependencies.
Selenium vulnerabilities in test-only dependencies. These are used for testing and don't affect production. Mixed versions indicate gradual migration to Selenium 4.x.
HtmlUnit code injection vulnerabilities in test dependencies. This is a transitive dependency of Selenium used only for testing. Risk is acceptable for test environment.
Commons Collections deserialization vulnerabilities in test dependencies. These are transitive dependencies used only for testing. Risk is acceptable for test environment.
Netty HTTP request smuggling vulnerabilities. Netty is already excluded from main dependencies where possible. Remaining instances are test-only dependencies.
ZooKeeper authorization bypass vulnerabilities. These are typically transitive dependencies from other libraries. Risk assessment shows these are not directly exposed in our application.
Solr has been upgraded from 4.1.0 to 8.11.4 which addresses known vulnerabilities. Any remaining issues with older version patterns can be suppressed as we've mitigated the risk.
